instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with only minor liquid damage on <TRANSISTOR>Q5158</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced but no change, Only 0.60V on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>


What should be checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Do you get correct voltage on all other coils?

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  starts directly with 0.6V, or drops in seconds from higher start voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
yes correct voltage on other coils

 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> starts directly with 0.6V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground there.
Compare with similar board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Compares same to other board not working as well

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Try heating CPU with quality flux.
May have luck to be only accumulated crap between its balls.
